p: Antiviral properties of chloroquine inÂ vitro have been observed for more than half a century [ 2]. It exerts its antiviral effect by several mechanisms: reducing endocytosis of virus by stabilising the lysosomes, inhibiting the viral replication, and inducing the production of non-infectious particles by inhibition of glycosylation of the envelope glycoproteins [ 3]. Additionally, it exerts anti-inflammatory effects by inhibiting the release of proinflammatory cytokines, especially tumor necrosis factor-alpha which may ameliorate the immune reaction seen with viral infections.
